quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 6 Quiz 1
quiz.subtitle: 6.1: Carbonyl Structure
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Fundamentals and naming of aldehydes and ketones

questions.question: What is the hybridisation of the carbon atom in a carbonyl group?
questions.explanation: The carbonyl carbon is bonded to three other atoms (one oxygen and two others) with one pi bond, giving it a trigonal planar geometry and $sp^{2}$ hybridisation.

questions.question: Which of the following describes the structural difference between an aldehyde and a ketone?
options: Aldehydes have at least one hydrogen attached to the carbonyl carbon; ketones have two alkyl/aryl groups.
Ketones have a hydrogen attached to the carbonyl carbon; aldehydes do not.
Aldehydes contain a nitrogen atom; ketones do not.
Ketones are only cyclic; aldehydes are always straight chains.
questions.explanation: An aldehyde ($R-CHO$) always has the carbonyl at the end of a chain, while a ketone ($R-CO-R'$) has it between two carbon groups.

questions.question: What is the IUPAC suffix used for naming aldehydes?
questions.explanation: Aldehydes use the suffix '-al'. For example, a two-carbon aldehyde is ethanal.

questions.question: What is the correct IUPAC name for $CH_{3}COCH_{2}CH_{3}$?
questions.explanation: The longest chain has four carbons, and the carbonyl group is at position 2, making it butan-2-one.

questions.question: The bond angles around the carbonyl carbon are approximately:
questions.explanation: Due to its $sp^{2}$ hybridisation and trigonal planar shape, the bond angles are approximately 120°.

questions.question: What is the common name for the simplest aldehyde, methanal?
questions.explanation: Methanal is widely known by its common name, formaldehyde.

questions.question: Which of the following is the correct IUPAC name for $C_{6}H_{5}CHO$?
questions.explanation: Benzaldehyde is the standard IUPAC name for an aldehyde group attached directly to a benzene ring.

questions.question: How is the parent chain numbered in an aldehyde?
options: The carbonyl carbon is always assigned as carbon-1
Numbering starts from the end furthest from the carbonyl
The chain is numbered to give substituents the lowest possible numbers
questions.explanation: Since the aldehyde group is always terminal, the carbonyl carbon is automatically C1.

questions.question: What is the general formula for a saturated acyclic aldehyde or ketone?
questions.explanation: Because they contain one double bond ($C=O$), they have two fewer hydrogens than an alcohol, resulting in $C_{n}H_{2n}O$.

questions.question: If a molecule contains both a ketone and an alcohol group, which group takes priority for the suffix in naming?
options: The group closer to the end of the chain
questions.explanation: Ketones and aldehydes have higher IUPAC priority than alcohols. The alcohol becomes a 'hydroxy' substituent.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered the basics of carbonyl structure and naming.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You have a solid handle on aldehyde and ketone nomenclature.
scoreMessages.50: Good progress. Remember to double-check your IUPAC priorities.
scoreMessages.0: Review the difference between the -al and -one suffixes.
